natural problem:
Is
\[f(x) = \log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})\]an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither".
natural solution: Note that \begin{align} -x + \sqrt{1 + (-x)^2} &= -x + \sqrt{1 + x^2} \\ &= \frac{(-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{-x^2 + (1 + x^2)}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \end{align}so

\begin{align} f(-x) &= \log (-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= \log \left( \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \right) \\ &= -\log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= -f(x). \end{align}Thus, $f(x)$ is an $\boxed{\text{odd}}$ function.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log (x + sqrt(1 + x powr 2))"
shows  "(\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)) = False"
and "(\<forall> x. f x = -f (-x)) = True"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Is
\[f(x) = \log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})\]an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} -x + \sqrt{1 + (-x)^2} &= -x + \sqrt{1 + x^2} \\ &= \frac{(-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{-x^2 + (1 + x^2)}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \end{align}so
 \begin{align} f(-x) &= \log (-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= \log \left( \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \right) \\ &= -\log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= -f(x). \end{align}Thus, $f(x)$ is an $\boxed{\text{odd}}$ function.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log (x + sqrt(1 + x powr 2))"
shows  "(\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)) = False"
and "(\<forall> x. f x = -f (-x)) = True"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider the function $f(x) = \log(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})$. Is it true that $f(x) = f(-x)$ for all $x$? The answer is no. Is it true that $f(x) = -f(-x)$ for all $x$? The answer is yes.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = ln (x + sqrt (1 + x powr 2))"
shows  "\<forall>x. f (-x) = - f x"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Is
\[f(x) = \log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})\]an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} -x + \sqrt{1 + (-x)^2} &= -x + \sqrt{1 + x^2} \\ &= \frac{(-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{-x^2 + (1 + x^2)}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \end{align}so
 \begin{align} f(-x) &= \log (-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= \log \left( \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \right) \\ &= -\log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= -f(x). \end{align}Thus, $f(x)$ is an $\boxed{\text{odd}}$ function.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = ln (x + sqrt (1 + x powr 2))"
shows  "\<forall>x. f (-x) = - f x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$, if $f(x) = \ln(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})$, then $f(-x) = -f(x)$.

a_2.informal problem: Show that for all real numbers $x$, the function $f(x) = \ln(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})$ satisfies the property $f(-x) = -f(x)$.

a_3.formal problem:
definition f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" where
"f x = log (x + sqrt (1 + x\<^sup>2))"

theorem
shows  "odd f"
proof (rule oddI)
  fix x
  have "f (- x) = log ((- x) + sqrt (1 + (- x)\<^sup>2))"
    unfolding f_def by simp
  also have "\<dots> = log (x + sqrt (1 + x\<^sup>2))"
    by (simp add: power2_eq_square sqrt_plus1_eq_neg)
  finally show "f (- x) = - f x"
    unfolding f_def by simp
qed

end
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Is
\[f(x) = \log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})\]an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} -x + \sqrt{1 + (-x)^2} &= -x + \sqrt{1 + x^2} \\ &= \frac{(-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{-x^2 + (1 + x^2)}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \end{align}so
 \begin{align} f(-x) &= \log (-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= \log \left( \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \right) \\ &= -\log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= -f(x). \end{align}Thus, $f(x)$ is an $\boxed{\text{odd}}$ function.
 *)



definition f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" where
"f x = log (x + sqrt (1 + x\<^sup>2))"

theorem
shows  "odd f"
proof (rule oddI)
  fix x
  have "f (- x) = log ((- x) + sqrt (1 + (- x)\<^sup>2))"
    unfolding f_def by simp
  also have "\<dots> = log (x + sqrt (1 + x\<^sup>2))"
    by (simp add: power2_eq_square sqrt_plus1_eq_neg)
  finally show "f (- x) = - f x"
    unfolding f_def by simp
qed

end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The function $f(x) = \log(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})$ is defined. Show that the function $f$ is an odd function. An odd function is a function that satisfies the property $f(-x) = -f(x)$ for all $x$ in the domain.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log (x + sqrt (1 + x powr 2))"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f (-x) = - f x"
shows  "odd f"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Is
\[f(x) = \log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})\]an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} -x + \sqrt{1 + (-x)^2} &= -x + \sqrt{1 + x^2} \\ &= \frac{(-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})(x + \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{-x^2 + (1 + x^2)}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \end{align}so
 \begin{align} f(-x) &= \log (-x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= \log \left( \frac{1}{x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \right) \\ &= -\log (x + \sqrt{1 + x^2}) \\ &= -f(x). \end{align}Thus, $f(x)$ is an $\boxed{\text{odd}}$ function.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log (x + sqrt (1 + x powr 2))"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f (-x) = - f x"
shows  "odd f"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
